conversation.content: [breathlessly] Oh, you're actually here—I thought you might show up when you saw my car, but these hawks need to be released at dawn for the best thermal currents.
Right, because clearly what this neighborhood needs is more predatory birds swooping at people's heads instead of the parking structure we've been petitioning for.
These red-tailed hawks were hit by cars on the highway specifically because we've destroyed ninety percent of their hunting grounds for strip malls and parking lots.
[dryly] How noble of you.
[animated] You know what's actually noble? This female hawk teaching her offspring to hunt in urban environments because that's all we've left them—adapting to our concrete disaster of a world.
Spare me the wildlife documentary narration, honestly, because some of us have real problems like nowhere to park when we get home from our actual jobs. [bitter laugh]
[growing heated] Your parking convenience doesn't trump an entire ecosystem that's been here for thousands of years before your SUV needed a designated spot.
Thousands of years, [snorts], and yet somehow civilization managed to happen anyway.
Civilization is currently experiencing the sixth mass extinction event, and we're losing eighteen species every single day while you're worried about walking an extra block from your car.
[sarcastically] Eighteen species a day? Well then, what's two more hawks in the grand scheme of your apocalypse? They'll probably get hit by cars again within the week.
[quieter] That's the thing though—these two survived against impossible odds, spent months in rehabilitation, and they're choosing to stay in this area despite everything.
Choosing? They're birds with bird brains making bird decisions based on instinct, not some inspirational comeback story you're projecting onto them.

Their brain-to-body ratio is actually comparable to primates, and they demonstrate complex problem-solving that would surprise you if you ever stopped assuming everything non-human is worthless. [exhales]
[defensive] I never said worthless, just less important than human needs—there's a housing crisis, people need parking, and you're out here playing Snow White.
[intensely] The housing crisis and the wildlife crisis are the same crisis—we've built unsustainably for decades, paved over wetlands that prevented flooding, clear-cut forests that cleaned our air.
So your solution is what exactly? We all live in trees and commune with the hawks while society collapses around us?
My solution is that we stop acting like the only species that matters while we're actively destroying our own life support systems—but sure, make it sound ridiculous. [frustrated]
[scoffing] Life support systems, you mean this patch of weeds and the occasional rat-eating bird that everyone else just sees as a nuisance?
[firmly] I mean the interconnected web that gives you breathable air, drinkable water, and a climate that doesn't cook you alive—but you're right, parking is definitely the priority here.
You know what? Release your birds, save the world one hawk at a time, and when you're done playing hero, the rest of us will still be here dealing with reality. [walking away]

scenario: A wildlife biologist encounters their cynical neighbor while releasing rehabilitated birds in the local park, the same park the neighbor wants bulldozed for a parking structure.
